tgt_text: I'm going to talk to you tonight about coming out of the closet, and not in the traditional sense, not just the gay closet.
speaker: spk.1932

tgt_text: I think we all have closets.
speaker: spk.1932

tgt_text: Your closet may be telling someone you love her for the first time, or telling someone that you're pregnant, or telling someone you have cancer, or any of the other hard conversations we have throughout our lives.
speaker: spk.1932

tgt_text: All a closet is is a hard conversation, and although our topics may vary tremendously, the experience of being in and coming out of the closet is universal.
speaker: spk.1932

tgt_text: It is scary, and we hate it, and it needs to be done.
speaker: spk.1932

tgt_text: Several years ago, I was working at the South Side Walnut Cafe, a local diner in town, and during my time there I would go through phases of militant lesbian intensity: not shaving my armpits, quoting Ani DiFranco lyrics as gospel.
speaker: spk.1932

tgt_text: And depending on the bagginess of my cargo shorts and how recently I had shaved my head, the question would often be sprung on me, usually by a little kid:
speaker: spk.1932

tgt_text: Um, are you a boy or are you a girl?
speaker: spk.1932

tgt_text: And there would be an awkward silence at the table.
speaker: spk.1932

tgt_text: I'd clench my jaw a little tighter, hold my coffee pot with a little more vengeance.
speaker: spk.1932
